q2.description: Recall that we defined a convention for accepting/rejecting whether an input string is in a specified language.
q2.question: When is a string accepted by a TM?
answer: If the TM halts in a final state
choices: If the TM halts in a final state
If the TM finishes execution in a non-final state
If the TM is found an undefined transition

q3.description: Recall that we defined a convention for accepting/rejecting whether an input string is in a specified language.
q3.question: When is a string rejected by a TM?
answer: If the TM finishes execution in a non-final state
If the TM is found an undefined transition
choices: If the TM halts in a final state
If the TM finishes execution in a non-final state
If the TM is found an undefined transition
correctFeedback: The key here is that the machine halts (with separate mechanisms for accept or reject).

q5.description: We define a language to be Turing-decidable if every string results in one of these two outcomes.
q5.question: A language is Turing-decideable if there exists a Turing machine that can clearly indicate for every string whether that string is in the language or not.

q7.description: We can define another concept: Turingâˆ’acceptable. We say that machine $M$ accepts a string $w$ if $M$ halts on input $w$. Then, $M$ accepts a language iff $M$ halts on $w$ iff $w \in L$.
q7.question: What will happen if the string $w$ is $\not \in$ the language?
q7.answer: The machine will go into an infinite loop
choices: Similar to turing decidable laguages, the machine will halt with reject status
The machine will go into an infinite loop

q9.description: So, a language is Turing-decidable if it halts on every input, in two different ways so that we can tell if the string is in the language or not. Separately, a language is Turing-acceptable if it halts on strings in the language, and does not halt on strings not in the language.
q9.question: The difference between Turing-decidable and Turing-acceptable is the machine behavior when the string is $\not \in $ the language.

q11.description:
Consider this example: $\Sigma_0 = \{a, b\}$, $L = \{w \in \Sigma^*_0: w$ contains at least one $a\}$.
$\qquad$ --------------------------------
$\qquad p\quad q\quad\delta(q, \sigma, {R,L,S})$
$\qquad$ --------------------------------
$\qquad q_0\quad a \quad (h, a, R)$
$\qquad q_0\quad b\quad (q_0, b, R)$
$\qquad q_0\quad \# \quad (q_0, \#, R)$
q11.question: What will happen if the tape has no $a$'s?
q11.answer: The machine will enter a infinite loop
choices: The machine will enter a infinite loop
The machine will reject the string

q12.description:
Consider this example: $\Sigma_0 = \{a, b\}$, $L = \{w \in \Sigma^*_0: w$ contains at least one $a\}$.
$\qquad$ --------------------------------
$\qquad p\quad q\quad\delta(q, \sigma, {R,L,S})$
$\qquad$ --------------------------------
$\qquad q_0\quad a \quad (h, a, R)$
$\qquad q_0\quad b\quad (q_0, b, R)$
$\qquad q_0\quad \# \quad (q_0, \#, R)$
q12.question: What is the type of this machine?

q13.description:
Consider this example: $\Sigma_0 = \{a, b\}$, $L = \{w \in \Sigma^*_0: w$ contains at least one $a\}$.
$\qquad$ --------------------------------
$\qquad p\quad q\quad\delta(q, \sigma, {R,L,S})$
$\qquad$ --------------------------------
$\qquad q_0\quad a \quad (h, a, R)$
$\qquad q_0\quad b\quad (q_0, b, R)$
$\qquad q_0\quad \# \quad (q_0, \#, R)$
q13.question: Which transition should we remove to make the machine be Turing decidable?
